subject: RE: [junit] Testing a class inside an Application Server
msgSnippet: Hi Michael,  How different is what you have described from http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/1.4/howto_tomcat.html ? Actually, what you described is
messageBody:
Hi Michael,

<biased>

How different is what you have described from
http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/1.4/howto_tomcat.html ?

Actually, what you described is exactly JUnitEE
(http://junitee.sourceforge.net/).

I agree with you, it starts simple and then you need some more features.
For example, you need to automate the tests as part of a build (this is
probably one of the most wanted feature). So you will start to have a
client part that calls your URL, parses the XML and display the result.
All is fine but then you also want to be able to execute the test from
any of the existing JUnit integration tools (from IDEs, using Ant junit
task, etc). So you will transform your client side into a TestCase so
that it can be run by any test runner ...

... and this is Cactus ! :-)

To summarise :

- yes Cactus can be a simple as what you describe (this is actually a
feature of version 1.4, which is not released yet - but soon to be)

- it allow for more should you need it

- it is documented and there are resources on Cactus : website + books +
articles

- BTW, Cactus integrates completely with Ant to automated start up and
shutdown of application servers

</biased>

Yes, I am the original author of Cactus and thus I am biased :-) but as
a user I would always go with existing framework if I find any that
perform what I want. For example, I wouldn't dare write my logging
framework, MVC controller one, XML to Java mapping one, etc.

In the end it is your choice. I'm just writing this email so that you
know Cactus does what you want and that you shouldn't skip it because
you think it doesn't.

Cheers,
-Vincent

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Michael Rettig [mailto:mrettig@...]
> Sent: 13 July 2002 02:45
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Testing a class inside an Application Server
>
>
> From: "Nicholas Lesiecki" <nick@...>
> > What you describe sounds very similar to Cactus:
> >
> > http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/
> >
> > Have you looked at it?
>
> Yes, and what I'm describing is far simpler than Cactus. There is no
> framework to speak of. Just a servlet that knows how to run a test
suite
> and return the results as xml. For instance, you would pass this URL
to
> your browser to run the tests in a remote app server.
>
> http://localhost:8080/junit?classname=com.package.test.TestCase
>
> It is very simple, but powerful. Since the test executes within the
> servlet container you can access all the facilities of the app server.
> We've also automated the startup and shutdown of the app server, so
the
> entire test process is completely scripted. This makes it simple to
plug
> the whole process into our cruise control build process.
>
> Mike
